lines.text: He said you have an illness. What kind of an illness?
You might call it a fracture in my soul, something which left me with a taste for oblivion.
I am sorry. I thought you were planning to stay a while. But perhaps my sense of smell deceives me.
I feel differently with you. Why should that be? You still the rage.
Where does it come from, Sir, this rage?
How should I know? It comes in like the tide.
I am the bandit. He is merely the cave in which I shelter.

[to Mary]
I always knew you'd be the death of us.

It was the only way he could devise to set you free. It was inevitable from the moment I found how to achieve what I'd always wanted... To be the knife as well as the wound. Would you have ever forgiven me? I wanted the night... you see... and here it is...
[last lines]
I wanted the night, you see. A - and here it is.
You said you didn't care what the world thought of you. Nor will I.

[referring to her first glimpse of Hyde]
He came out of the dark as if he was made of it.
My answer is always "Yes!"
Is Evil stronger than Good?
You tell me.
Haven't you ever wished for a completely new life, Mary?
No sir. What good would that do?
I mean, suppose you were able to do absolutely whatever you wanted, with no consequences and no regrets? Then what?
I don't believe there's such a thing as actions without consequences.
Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde would like some tea.
[first lines]
I'm not going to bite you.
I'm sorry, sir, you gave me a fright.
You're up very early.
I'm generally up by five, sir, otherwise I get behind.
When we had our talk, you refused to say you hated your father.
I don't.
Why not?
He put a dark place in me and I can't forgive him for that, but it's part of me now, and how can I regret what I am? Though it often makes me sad.
Oh, well, sadness, yes, that can't helped. That comes in like the tide.

[Upon seeing her mother's corpse]
A poor wage for a lifetime's drudgery!
